blocks.text: MRI-based approach to hamstring anatomy, BAMIC grading, partial vs full-thickness tears, and nerve involvement.
Source: Radiology Assistant "Hamstring injury". Images stored locally.
Introduction
MRI refines the clinical diagnosis by distinguishing partial from full-thickness hamstring tears and guiding prognosis or surgical need.

items: Full-thickness tears usually involve the free tendons or ischial tuberosity insertion; decision point is whether repair is required.
Partial-thickness injuries most often involve the musculotendinous or musculofascial junction and are typically managed conservatively.
Goal of imaging: determine prognosis and timeline for return to play.

blocks.text: Anatomy
Hamstrings include biceps femoris, semitendinosus, and semimembranosus; conjoint tendon arises from biceps femoris long head and semitendinosus, innervated by the sciatic nerve.

items: Biceps femoris: long head from ischial tuberosity, short head from linea aspera; inserts on fibular head.
Semitendinosus: largely tendinous, medial to biceps femoris, covers most of semimembranosus.
Semimembranosus: broad, flattened, deeper muscle; tendon inserts lateral on ischial tuberosity while muscle belly lies medial.
Musculotendinous junction marks transition to intramuscular tendon; fascia surrounds the muscle.
Mnemonic for tendon positions on axial view: CaraMel = Conjoint medial; StracciatelLa = Semimembranosus lateral.

blocks.text: Pathology Specimen
Posterior specimen shows conjoint tendon attached to sacrotuberous ligament; semitendinosus fibers also attach directly to the tuberosity while semimembranosus inserts lateral.

items: Sacrotuberous ligament can limit retraction if the conjoint tendon remains connected after avulsion.
Sciatic nerve lies ~1 cm lateral to the proximal hamstring attachment.
Aponeurotic connection between sacrotuberous ligament and superficial conjoint tendon may remain intact even when tendons avulse.

blocks.text: BAMIC Classification
British Athletics Muscle Injury Classification: grades 0-3 are partial-thickness, grade 4 is full-thickness.

items: Suffix a/b/c denotes intramuscular location: myofascial, musculotendinous, or intratendinous involvement.
Grade 4 indicates complete tear with or without retraction.
Classification captures edema length and tendon distortion to aid prognosis and rehab planning.

blocks.text: Partial Thickness Injury
Most partial injuries occur at the musculotendinous junction; reporting should capture edema length and intramuscular tendon distortion.

items: Edema surrounds the intramuscular tendon in a feathered pattern; measure total edema length.
Tendon changes (thickening, waviness, high signal) reflect higher-grade strain; measure length of distorted tendon.
Use axial images to confirm coronal impressions and compare with contralateral side.
Partial-thickness injuries are treated non-operatively with phased rehab.

blocks.text: Full Thickness Injury
Full-thickness tears involve free tendon or insertion, often with retraction; measurement guides surgical decision-making.

items: Loss of tendon continuity with retraction from ischial tuberosity; gaps may favor operative repair when >2 cm.
Direct measurement: coronal fluid-sensitive sequence from ischial tuberosity origin to proximal tendon stump.
Document which tendon is torn (semimembranosus vs conjoint) and degree of retraction.

blocks.text: Dropped Icecream Sign
Axial view analogy: ischial tuberosity is the cone; semimembranosus and conjoint tendons are two scoops (StracciatelLa lateral, CaraMel medial).

items: Identify which tendon is avulsed by noting which scoop dropped.
Both scoops down indicates avulsion of both semimembranosus and conjoint tendons.

blocks.text: Apophysiolysis
In adolescents, proximal hamstring injury often represents avulsion of the ischial apophysis (weakest link) rather than tendon disruption.

items: CT or MRI shows avulsed apophysis; tendon and musculotendinous junction typically remain intact.
Consider surgical referral when significant displacement is present.

blocks.text: Ischiadic Nerve Involvement
Edema around the proximal hamstring may encase or flatten the sciatic nerve; imaging findings correlate poorly with symptoms but should be reported.

items: Look for nerve enlargement, flattening, intraneural edema, surrounding hematoma, or fibrosis.
Extensive hematoma in the fascia can surround the nerve even with partial tendon injury.

blocks.text: Follow Up
Healed partial tears often leave fibrous scarring; postoperative studies may show anchors and fatty atrophy.

items: Old injury: fibrous scar at prior tear site is common even when tendon otherwise appears normal.
Reinsertion: after avulsion repair, note anchors at the tuberosity and any muscle fatty atrophy.

blocks.text: MRI Protocol
Protocol emphasizes coronal overview and axial detail; scan both legs for comparison and focus on coronal/axial planes.

items: Coronal T2 fat-saturated (fatsat/STIR/Dixon) for overview and measuring edema or retraction.
Axial PD fat-saturated (fatsat/Dixon) through injury zone for edema or hematoma assessment.
Axial T2 high-resolution from origin to insertion to characterize tendon fibers; usually two stacks.
Cover entire hamstring complex bilaterally; sagittal plane is less helpful for anatomy.
